questions.question: Pump failure during circulation. First action?
questions.explanation: First: secure the well. Shut in to trap pressure and maintain BHP. Then troubleshoot pump while well is safely controlled.

questions.question: Kelly hose splits during kill. First action?

options.C: Stop pump; close string valve; close choke
options.D: Stop pump; close choke; close string valve

questions.explanation: Stop pump immediately. Close STRING VALVE first to prevent backflow up the split hose, then close choke to trap pressure. Order matters!

questions.question: How to detect losses during kill?
questions.explanation: Losses = mud going into formation. Pit level drops. SPM stays same (pumping); flowline shows what comes back (but doesn't show what's lost downhole).

questions.question: Danger of MGS pressure buildup?
questions.explanation: MGS over-pressure forces gas out at mud discharge, into shaker area—occupied workspace. Explosion/H2S risk. Doesn't affect downhole conditions or vent line.

questions.question: How to detect losses during second Driller's circulation? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Losses: Pit level drops (B) as mud goes to formation. Must CLOSE choke to maintain FCP (D)—less mud returning requires more backpressure.

questions.question: Pump leaking but DP pressure held constant. BHP effect?
questions.explanation: Leak means less flow reaching annulus. If you're closing choke to maintain DP pressure, you're adding backpressure beyond what reduced flow requires. BHP increases.

questions.question: Plugged drill pipe - what can't you calculate? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Plugged pipe = no SIDPP = can't determine formation pressure (B) or kill mud weight (E). Hydrostatic known from mud weight. Fracture from LOT. Shoe calculated from known values.

questions.question: Pressures build then drop before stabilising. Cause?
questions.explanation: Build (pressure increasing) then drop (formation fractures, fluid flows in) = weak zone breakdown. Serious situation requiring modified approach.

questions.question: Choke adjusted +150 psi. Effect on shoe pressure, BHP, choke pressure?
questions.explanation: More choke restriction = more backpressure everywhere. All pressures downstream of choke increase (transmitted through fluid column).

questions.question: How to recognize choke washout?
questions.explanation: Washout = erosion opening choke. Pressure drops. Must continually CLOSE to maintain target. If opening = plugging, opposite problem.

questions.question: SPM increased. Casing pressure action?
questions.explanation: Casing pressure reflects BHP. Changing pump speed shouldn't change BHP. Adjust choke to hold casing constant despite SPM change.

questions.question: How to recognize choke plugging?

options.A: Pump pressure decrease; no casing change
options.C: Casing pressure decrease; no pump change

questions.explanation: Plugging restricts flow. Pressure builds. Must continually CLOSE (reduce opening) to compensate for natural restriction. Wait—that's backwards. Plugging BUILDS pressure, so you OPEN to relieve. If CLOSING = washout.

questions.question: String washout - choke closed to maintain pressure. BHP effect?
questions.explanation: Washout reduces circulating pressure. Closing choke adds backpressure. If you're closing to maintain DP (which is artificially low from washout), you're over-pressuring annulus. BHP increases.

questions.question: String washout, no choke adjustment. What changes?
questions.explanation: Washout reduces system resistance. With constant pump rate and no choke adjustment, casing pressure drops (less restriction). DP pressure also drops. MAASP and frac P are well properties—unchanged.

questions.question: SICP 0 psi, SIDPP 435 psi, no annulus flow. Cause?
questions.explanation: SIDPP exists (formation pressure) but SICP = 0 (annulus not seeing it) with no flow = packed off. Pressure trapped in DS, not transmitted to annulus.

questions.question: Small losses during kill. How to reduce weak zone pressure?

options.B: Reduce pump speed; keep BHP near formation pressure
options.C: Stop circulation; shut in; manage via Volumetric Method

questions.explanation: Small losses = marginal situation. Reduce pump speed (less friction, less pressure). Keep BHP just above formation (minimum safe overbalance). Don't stop unless losses worsen.

questions.question: Nozzle plugged. BHP effect if no action taken?
questions.explanation: Nozzle plugging changes WHERE pressure is lost (more at bit, less below). BHP at formation unchanged if total system pressure maintained by choke adjustment.

questions.question: Choke washout recognition?
questions.explanation: Washout = erosion = bigger opening = less restriction = pressures DROP. Both DP and casing fall as backpressure bleeds off through eroded choke.

questions.question: Kill at 35 spm (DP 700, Casing 1000). Speed drops to 25 spm, holding casing at 1000. BHP?
questions.explanation: Lower speed = less friction = less circulating ECD. If casing held constant (not increased to compensate), BHP actually decreases. Should let casing rise to maintain BHP.

questions.question: Casing approaching MAASP, influx still in open hole. Action?

options.A: Operate choke to prevent exceeding MAASP

questions.explanation: Near MAASP with influx in open hole = balancing act. Can't just hold MAASP (may underbalance). Minimize excess while maintaining slight overbalance. May need to accept small MAASP exceedance.

questions.question: BHP effects: (a) Increase SPM 20→30 holding DP constant; (b) Pump kill mud to bit holding DP constant
questions.explanation: (a) Higher SPM = more friction. If DP constant, choke must open = less backpressure = BHP drops. (b) Kill mud adds hydrostatic in DS. If DP constant, that extra hydrostatic goes to BHP.

questions.question: Horizontal well, casing pressure increases rapidly when gas enters vertical section. Why?

options.B: Kill mud not pumped from start
options.D: No hydrostatic head loss until gas reaches inclined/vertical

questions.explanation: In horizontal section, gas migration doesn't reduce hydrostatic (no vertical movement). Once gas enters vertical/inclined section, it suddenly gains buoyancy and reduces hydrostatic rapidly.

questions.question: Pump speed increased. To maintain constant BHP, pump pressure should?
questions.explanation: Higher speed = more friction. Pump pressure = BHP + friction. If BHP constant and friction increases, pump pressure must rise.

questions.question: 25 bbl gas condensate kick. Pump fails, influx migrating. Holding casing constant at 700 psi. BHP?
questions.explanation: Gas migration while holding surface constant = BHP drops. The gas 'pushes' pressure to surface. To maintain BHP, should allow casing to rise then bleed (volumetric).
